lines.gurmukhi: jYsy jl kUp inksq jqn kIey sIcIAq Kyq eykY phucq n Awn kau
lines.transliteration_english: Jaisay Jal Koop Nikasat Jatan Keeay , Seecheeat Khayt Aykai Pahouchat N Aan Kau ?

Shabad OS B.translation: Just as water from a well can be drawn by different methods, such as bucket and rope, Persian wheel etc. and then it is directed to irrigate a field and it goes nowhere else.

lines.gurmukhi: piQk ppIhw ipAwsy Aws lig iFg bYiT ibnu gunu BwNjn qiRpiq kq pRwn kau
lines.transliteration_english: Padik Papeehaa Piaasay Aas Lagi Ddhig Baitthi , Binu Gounu Bhaanjan Tripati Kat Praan Kau ?

Shabad OS B.translation: A traveller and a rain-bird may keep on sitting thirsty near a well but cannot quench their thirst without means to draw water from the well and therefore cannot assuage their thirst.

lines.gurmukhi: qYsy hI skl dyv tyv sY trq nwih syvw kIey dyq Pl kwmnw smwin kau
lines.transliteration_english: Taisay Hee Sakal Dayv Tayv Sai Tarat Naahi , Sayvaa Keeay Dayt Dhal Kaamanaa Samaani Kau ?

Shabad OS B.translation: Likewise, all gods and goddesses can do something within their power. They can reward a devotee for his services only to that extent and that too of worldly desires.

lines.gurmukhi: pUrn bHm gur brKw AMmiRq ihiq brK hriK dyq srb inDwn kau ]451]
lines.transliteration_english: Pooran Braham Gur Barakhaa Anmrit Hiti , Barakh Harakhi Dayt Sarab Nidhaan Kau ?451?

Shabad OS B.translation: But the complete and perfect God-like True Guru showers the spiritual pleasure-giving ambrosial nectar of Naam, the treasure-house of all the happiness and comforts. (The service of gods and goddesses is trivial in benefits whereas that of True Guru bless
